item.title: Asymmetric Encryption
item.description:
What Is Asymmetric Encryption? #

Asymmetric encryption, also known as public-key encryption, is a method of encrypting data that involves two separate keys: a public key and a private key. These keys are mathematically linked but not identical, hence the term “asymmetric.” This method provides a secure way of encrypting and decrypting information, and it’s widely used in various forms of digital communication and security protocols

How Does It Work? #

Key Generation: #

A pair of cryptographic keys is generated. The process involves complex algorithms like RSA or ECC, ensuring that these keys are mathematically linked. The public key is designed to be shared, while the private key is kept confidential by the owner.

item.title: Session vs Token
item.description:
Introduction #

Both sessions and tokens are used for user authentication and maintaining user state across multiple HTTP requests in a web application.

Process #

Session-Based Authentication Process #

  • 1-2: User Login Attempt

    • The user submits their login credentials (usually username and password) through the client (e.g., a web browser).

  • 3-4: Credentials Verification

    • The server receives the credentials and verifies them against its user database or authentication source.

  • 5-6: Session Creation

TLS/SSL and HTTPS #

TLS (Transport Layer Security) and its predecessor, SSL (Secure Sockets Layer), are integral to HTTPS, which stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, the primary protocol used for transmitting web pages over the internet. This post will introduce the process of TLS handshake, and the TLS version is TLS 1.2

item.title: TLS Handshake: Server Hello
item.description:
TLS Handshake: Server Hello #

After a client sends the ClientHello message to initiate a secure connection, the server responds with ServerHello. This message finalizes the parameters needed to establish an encrypted session, and it’s the server’s way of saying:

“Here’s what I’ve selected from your offers. Let’s proceed securely.”

In this post, we’ll break down the ServerHello message, how to view it, and what its key components mean.

item.title: TLS Handshake: Certificate
item.description:
TLS Handshake: Certificate #

What is a TLS Certificate? #

During the TLS handshake, the server sends its certificate to the client to prove its identity. This certificate contains the server’s public key and information about who issued the certificate (a Certificate Authority). The client uses this certificate to verify that it’s really talking to the correct server, and then uses the public key to help create a secure, encrypted connection.
